etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Thomas Coryate (?1577–1617), traveller and writer. From Italian ducatone from ducato + -one

definitions: Any of various (typically large) silver coins; specifically (a) a silver coin of a type issued by various Italian states during the 17th and 18th centuries, initially created to be the same value as the gold ducat; (b) any of various similar coins issued elsewhere (especially in the Netherlands) during the same period and widely used for trade, particularly in areas controlled by the Dutch Republic.
